newsitem.title: COTE D'IVOIRE: U.S. firm starts cellular service in Ivory Coast. [CORRECTED 15:30 GMT]
newsitem.headline: U.S. firm starts cellular service in Ivory Coast. [CORRECTED 15:30 GMT]

text.p: Ivory Coast's first cellular telephone service went live this week after the U.S. operator signed a long-delayed tariff accord with the government, company officials said on Wednesday.

"We finally have a tariff," said Michael Phillips, Managing Director of Comstar Cellular S.A., a wholly-owned subsidiary of Boston-based International Wireless. "We went on line on Monday with approximately 2,000 subscribers." he told Reuters.
A second cellular network, Societe Ivorienne de Mobiles (SIM), indirectly owned by France Telecom, expects to start a full service on Friday.

"SIM will start its service on October 25," said Henri Neuville, the local head of state-owned France Telecom, whose unit France Cable Radio owns 70 percent of SIM. He put SIM's startup subscriber base at around 300.
Three companies were licensed by regulatory authority, Ivory Coast Telecommunications Agency, to provide cellular services under the country's economic reform and liberalisation plan.

But the telephone monopoly CI-TELCOM has until now been unable to conclude an inter-connection accord with the private operators setting out how much they would pay for being connected to the public network.

Comstar, which said it invested $70 million in Ivory Coast, also complained previously that tariffs set out by CI-TELCOM in a draft accord would make the cost of a local cellular phone call excessive.

"We had a good deal from CI-TELCOM, but we had to go to the (regulatory) agency to get the deal," Phillips said. "We wanted them to lower the rate because the cost of completing a local call in Abidjan would have been too much for most subscribers."

The new deal forming part of a one-year tariff accord, sets the cost of a local call in Abidjan at 155 CFA francs. If CI-TELCOM had not lowered its interconnection tariff a similar call would cost 30 percent more, Phillips said.

The third cellular operator, Loteny Telecom S.A., whose partners include U.S.-based Telecel International, launched a publicity blitz last month but there was no indication it was ready to start a service this month as it promised.
The Ivory Coast cellular market is projected at a modest 7,000 to 10,000 subscribers, and competition among the three operators is already fierce.
